questiontext.text: In a Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling, an aryl iodide and an aryl chloride are reacted separately under identical conditions with the same Pd(0)/phosphine catalyst. Which statement best predicts the relative rate of oxidative addition?

generalfeedback.text: Oxidative addition of Pd(0) into a C–X bond is strongly influenced by the nature of the halide, and aryl iodides are generally more reactive than aryl chlorides toward oxidative addition because the C–I bond is weaker and iodide is a better leaving group in this context. The other choices ignore the standard reactivity trend emphasized for cross-coupling electrophiles and incorrectly attribute the rate to sterics or “bond polarization only” without considering oxidative addition feasibility.

answer.text: Aryl chloride undergoes oxidative addition faster due to stronger C–Cl bond polarization
Aryl iodide undergoes oxidative addition faster due to better leaving group ability of iodide
Both proceed at the same rate because oxidative addition depends only on palladium, not halide
Aryl chloride undergoes oxidative addition faster because chloride is smaller and less steric

questiontext.text: A student wants to form a biaryl bond using a coupling that typically requires a base to enable transmetalation. Which reagent pair best matches this requirement?

generalfeedback.text: Suzuki–Miyaura coupling uses boronic acids/esters and commonly relies on hydroxide/alkoxide base to facilitate transmetalation from boron to palladium. Organotin partners correspond to Stille coupling (not base-driven in the same defining way), organozinc corresponds to Negishi coupling, and Grignard corresponds to Kumada coupling and is typically less functionally tolerant.

answer.text: Aryl bromide + organotin (R–SnBu3)
Aryl bromide + boronic acid/boronic ester
Aryl bromide + organozinc reagent
Aryl bromide + Grignard reagent (RMgX)

questiontext.text: In the Heck reaction, the formation of an alkene product is closely associated with which elementary step after migratory insertion?

generalfeedback.text: The Heck mechanism features oxidative addition, alkene insertion, and then β-hydride elimination to generate the substituted alkene (commonly giving E-alkene) and a Pd–H species. Reductive elimination is the C–C bond-forming step in many cross-couplings, but the Heck product alkene arises via β-hydride elimination after insertion rather than a final reductive elimination to create the alkene framework.

answer.text: Transmetalation
β-Hydride elimination
Reductive elimination
Radical recombination

questiontext.text: A terminal alkyne is coupled with an aryl bromide to give an aryl-alkyne under Pd catalysis. Which additional component most directly explains the commonly used co-catalyst role in this transformation?

generalfeedback.text: In Sonogashira coupling, Cu(I) commonly forms a copper acetylide from the terminal alkyne, enabling efficient transfer of the alkynyl group to palladium during transmetalation. Fluoride activation is characteristic of Hiyama coupling (organosilanes), while strong-acid vinyl cation pathways and Ti(III) radical reductions are not the defining mechanistic features described for Sonogashira in this unit.

answer.text: Copper(I) helps generate a metal acetylide that transfers the alkynyl group during transmetalation
Fluoride activates the alkyne by forming a pentavalent silicon ate complex
Strong acid protonates the alkyne to form a vinyl cation intermediate
Titanium(III) reduces the aryl bromide to an aryl radical

questiontext.text: A chemist must choose among Negishi, Kumada, and Hiyama couplings for a substrate bearing a base-sensitive functional group. Which choice is most consistent with selecting the coupling that is described as operating under comparatively mild activation (via fluoride) and improved functional group tolerance?

generalfeedback.text: Hiyama coupling uses organosilane partners and is described as fluoride-mediated in transmetalation/activation, often allowing mild conditions and good functional group tolerance. Kumada uses organomagnesium/organometallic partners that are typically more reactive and less tolerant, Negishi uses organozinc (not fluoride activation as a defining feature here), and Stille still proceeds via transmetalation (and is not among the three options being compared in the prompt).

answer.text: Kumada, because organomagnesium reagents are mild and tolerate many groups
Negishi, because organozinc reagents require fluoride activation
Hiyama, because organosilanes can be fluoride-activated and are used under mild conditions
Stille, because it avoids transmetalation

questiontext.text: A palladium-catalyzed allylic substitution proceeds via a π-allyl palladium intermediate and can give either linear or branched products depending on steric/electronic effects and ligand choice. Which named reaction best matches this description?

generalfeedback.text: Tsuji–Trost reactions are defined by formation of a π-allyl–Pd intermediate followed by nucleophilic attack, with regioselectivity (linear vs branched) and enantioselectivity influenced by substrate and ligands. Heck and Suzuki are cross-coupling families with different key intermediates/steps, while McMurry is a low-valent titanium-mediated carbonyl coupling to alkenes.

answer.text: Tsuji–Trost allylic substitution
Heck reaction
Suzuki–Miyaura coupling
McMurry reaction

questiontext.text: A student observes formation of an unwanted “biaryl byproduct” when performing Suzuki coupling with a boronic acid. Which adjustment is most directly targeted at the stated special-case issue in Suzuki reactions?

generalfeedback.text: The unit explicitly highlights “boronic acid homocoupling prevention” as a special consideration in Suzuki coupling and links optimization to ligand and base selection. Fluoride activation is tied to Hiyama, titanium reagents are tied to McMurry, and copper(I) co-catalysis is characteristic of Sonogashira rather than Suzuki.

answer.text: Add fluoride to activate silicon
Choose conditions that prevent boronic acid homocoupling (optimize ligand/base)
Replace Pd with low-valent titanium reagent
Use copper(I) to generate an alkynide intermediate

questiontext.text: A ring-closing metathesis (RCM) is planned to convert a diene into a cyclic alkene. Which catalyst family is most directly associated with this transformation in the syllabus unit?

generalfeedback.text: Olefin metathesis in this unit is described as proceeding with ruthenium-based catalysts (including common Grubbs/Hoveyda families) and includes RCM as a key application. Palladium-phosphine cycles describe cross-coupling; copper acetylide chemistry is Sonogashira; and Ti(III) conditions describe McMurry carbonyl coupling.

answer.text: Ruthenium alkylidene (Grubbs/Hoveyda-type) catalysts
Palladium-phosphine catalysts used for oxidative addition/transmetalation cycles
Copper(I) acetylide catalysts used for terminal alkyne coupling
Titanium(III) reagents used for carbonyl–carbonyl coupling

questiontext.text: A vinyl halide is coupled with an alkene under Heck conditions. The product is predominantly an E-alkene. Which mechanistic feature best rationalizes the typical E-alkene outcome in this reaction family?

generalfeedback.text: The Heck reaction is described with syn addition (insertion) and a β-hydride elimination pathway, and this sequence is associated with formation of E-alkene products in typical cases. π-allyl palladium intermediates define Tsuji–Trost chemistry, transmetalation is not the defining step for Heck (it uses alkene insertion instead), and radical-chain framing is not the core mechanism emphasized here.

answer.text: The reaction proceeds through a π-allyl palladium intermediate that enforces E geometry
Syn addition followed by β-hydride elimination commonly leads to E-alkene formation
The base-catalyzed transmetalation step sets the E/Z ratio
The reaction is a radical chain process that selectively forms E-alkenes

questiontext.text: Two aldehydes are subjected to low-valent titanium conditions to form an alkene. Which statement best captures the reaction’s key mechanistic logic at the 2-mark (intermediate) level?

generalfeedback.text: McMurry coupling is described as a titanium(III)/low-valent titanium-mediated carbonyl coupling where carbonyl reduction and coupling give a pinacol-like intermediate (often represented as a Ti–O–Ti bridged species) that leads to net deoxygenative olefination. The other options incorrectly import Pd cross-coupling steps (oxidative addition/transmetalation/reductive elimination), Suzuki logic, or π-allyl chemistry from Tsuji–Trost. (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/0d13af76-414f-4c3b-8d8c-2f6b625d3637/organic_unit_05.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/eecdaa56-93b9-4e87-bc04-9974af604151/inorganic_unit_07.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/f41187d8-4c1f-42a8-b69c-1b08ca48bd7f/organic_unit_04.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/bbb354c7-10b6-4c64-93aa-f65f58d9fb78/organic_unit_07.txt) (https://ppl-ai-file-upload.s3.amazonaws.com/web/direct-files/collection_99e4096c-742b-4ed1-9fa1-79a24cd1a07e/d56907a9-060e-4d86-bddd-81839e191ded/organic_unit_08.txt)

answer.text: Aldehydes first undergo oxidative addition to titanium, then transmetalation, then reductive elimination
Carbonyls are reduced to ketyl-like species that couple (pinacol-type intermediate) and ultimately deoxygenate to an alkene
Aldehydes undergo base-promoted transmetalation from boron, then reductive elimination
Aldehydes form a π-allyl complex that is attacked by a nucleophile
